an3.53:4.1: Then a brahmin went up to the Buddha,
an3.53:4.3: Seated to one side he said to the Buddha:
an3.53:4.4: “Master Gotama, they speak of ‘a teaching realizable in this very life’.
an3.53:4.5: In what way is the teaching realizable in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves?”
an3.53:5.1: “A greedy person, overcome and overwhelmed by greed, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.53:5.2: When greed has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.53:5.9: This is how the teaching is realizable in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
an3.53:6.1: A hateful person, overcome by hate, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.53:6.2: When hate has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.53:6.3: This, too, is how the teaching is realizable in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
an3.53:7.1: A deluded person, overcome by delusion, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.53:7.2: When delusion has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.53:7.3: This, too, is how the teaching is realizable in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”
an3.53:8.2: As if he was righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark
an3.53:8.3: so people with good eyes can see what’s there,
an3.53:8.4: Master Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
an3.53:8.5: I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the Dharma, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
an3.53:8.6: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
